context: Meh. As long as it didn't bring the bird down

The leading edge of the right tailplane appears to be sheetmetal (as opposed to composite). That said, it looks like it got hit by something traveling at a significant velocity. Either that or it was punctured by something metallic. Most parts in a typical drone are plastic, and so less likely to puncture.

replies.context: You would think that the amount of air turbulence that those chopper blades put off would force most all drones down and away from the back end of a chopper.

Since most main rotors turn clockwise, damage to the right tailplane might hint at the object hitting the blades first, then being propelled by them forcefully enough to cause the damage even with a lighter drone. Any other associated debris could have just missed the tail rotor.

If you look closely at the pictures you will realize the damage is to the leading edge of the horizontal stabilizer. Impact would have been very significant even with a small drone due to forward speed of helicopter.

replies.context:
"While the Supreme Court hasn't explicitly accepted that as the upper limit of property ownership, it's a useful guideline in trespass cases. Therefore, unless you own some very tall buildings, your private airspace probably ends somewhere between 80 and 500 feet above the ground"
 
Had to research that one.  Yes, airspace directly above your home is your private property..to a point.  I've seen some potato cannons that have been modified to launch nets to stop drones.
At least to the top of the chimney, right?

You can use the airspace above your home... you still don't own it.  VERY different concepts.  That is why you can put up say a large antenna, or let tall trees grow there.  

The armchair laywers that keep spewing this are flat out wrong.  The case law they keep citing has to do with use of the land, and repayment for damages.   Again, use.  Not ownership.  The FAA controls all airspace.  They have EXPLICITLY said they control all air space from the where the blades of grass end, up.
And you still won't hit it unless its hovering or moving slowly. You'll miss by a mile if it's moving.

As for the helicopter, they need to abide by the rules too and stay out of the 400ft airspace unless landing in designated areas. I have had 2 incidents (close calls) with helicopters. I realize this copter was at 1,100 ft

when drones cost "professional" prices, like sophisticated R/C planes ( I'm a professionally certified R/C/hot air balloon pilot btw) that were previously used for things like inspections etc we'll see a reduction in risk, but the advent of the $150 model and poorly implemented registration/geo fence system has me wondering if these things flooded the market with a secondary intent. unless licensed you should have a 150 ft limit on these toys. we don't license kites do we?
